United States Attorney, Eric Himpton Holder Jr., was born January 21, 1951 to parents from Saint Joseph and Saint Phillip of Barbados. Holder was the first African American to serve as Attorney General of the United States under President Barack Obama. He was able to attend the prestigious Stuyvesant High school in New York City. Holder also attended Columbia University and Columbia Law School for his Bachelor degree and Juris Doctorate. Some of his distinguished achievements include serving as an associate judge under former President Ronald Reagan. Holder also made history when President Bill Clinton nominated him as the deputy attorney general. He was the first African American to hold both positions. He is known for his work in civil rights and his impressive work with philanthropy for various causes. Eric Holder will be known as the judge, lawyer, and political advisor that helped to break the glass ceiling for people of color especially in the legal field. #BHM #USVIdelegate

Social activist, Marcus Garvey, was born on August 17, 1887, in St‚Äô Ann‚Äôs Jamaica. Garvey was the founder of the Universal Negro Improvement Association that was dedicated to promoting African-American resettlement in Africa. He was one of the most prominent orators of the Black Nationalism and Pan-Africanism, movements. He then went on to create a Pan-African philosophy that inspired a mass movement, known as Garveyism.   When Garvey migrated to the United States, he launched several businesses that promoted a separate black nation. Garvey would eventually go on to inspire the Nation of Islam and the Rastafarian movement. Marcus Garvey passed away in London in 1940 after suffering from several strokes. His body was not immediately taken to Jamaica because of World War II. In 1964, Garvey‚Äôs remains were exhumed, and then relocated to Jamaica. The government proclaimed him Jamaica‚Äôs first national hero, and re-interred him at a shrine in National Heroes Park.   Garvey‚Äôs legacy left a lasting impact on the civil rights movements and inspired many political activists. Many notable black political activists can still recognize his contributions today. #BHM #BlackHistory #USVIdelegate

David Hamilton Jackson was born in St. Croix on September 28, 1884. He was one of the foremost figures in the struggle for civil rights and workers' rights on St. Croix. He successfully petitioned Denmark for freedom of the press in 1915 and organized the islands' first labor union in 1916. Following the transfer of the territory to American control in 1917, he lobbied for US citizenship for the islanders. Hamilton Jackson established the first black newspaper in the Virgin Islands. It was called The Herald. November 1 (Liberty Day, or Bull and Bread Day), is celebrated as a public holiday in the Virgin Islands in honor of Hamilton Jackson‚Äôs many accomplishments. #VirginIslandsHistory #USVI100 #USVIDelegate #VI00

The Honorable Kenneth Mapp Governor The Virgin Islands of the United States Government House Charlotte Amalie, VI  00802   Dear Governor Mapp:   I am writing to you to express my concern about the ongoing hurricane recovery efforts in the U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI). The recent hurricanes have brought devastation to our three islands unlike anything experienced in recent history.  Recovery and rebuilding efforts will require an extraordinary level of coordination and cooperation between local and federal government, along with private sector partnerships from local, national, and international businesses and organizations. We have in this moment both an opportunity and a responsibility to ensure that the greatest good emerges from this calamity to our Virgin Islands.  This is an opportunity to not just rebuild but to create an exponentially better Virgin Islands; advancing technologies, mitigating energy issues and creating resilience in our critical infrastructures.   As the elected representative of the Virgin Islands in Congress, it is my duty and responsibility to advocate, legislate, and support the needs of the residents in the territory at the federal level.  The people of the USVI are best served by all hands not only working, but working together.  I have assured you on a number of occasions that I stand ready to support the local government and our people during this time.  Unfortunately, you have neither engaged in any outreach to my office on any substantive matter related to either Hurricanes Irma or Maria, nor have you sought to partner with my office on any requests from the USVI to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), or other legislative/funding requests to Congress.     My staff has been working tirelessly ‚Äì as we all remain indebted to your agency heads, officials and government staff for doing the same ‚Äì to ensure that the USVI can meet its needs during this time of crisis.  In these disasters, however, the people of the Virgin Islands are best served when local government coordinates with its Congressional office so that the elected delegate to Washington can advocate on behalf of the territorial government to federal authorities, or to be in a position to support and help validate your requests when federal and Congressional stakeholders, more often than not, seek our position on such appeals.     One example of this lack of coordination to date is on the issue of local housing.  FEMA officials have indicated that you have been presented options for temporary housing for individuals requiring such assistance; however, plans ‚Äì if any exist ‚Äì have not been communicated to my office.  While you very well may have formally requested some form of federal housing assistance, I have received no indication from federal authorities of any request made to receive assistance through FEMA‚Äôs Rapid Repair Program, which, depending on the extent of home damage, could help provide immediate support so that displaced individuals can get back in their homes.   Another example is in outreach and coordination with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The agency just this week has finally begun water safety testing in homes ‚Äì indeed a critical service for VI residents.  Unfortunately, in subsequent conversations I have had with federal officials, EPA was not even aware that many homes received water from cisterns instead of potable sources.  Surely we can work together on something as simple as ensuring a federal agency has a true understanding of the local residential infrastructure so its personnel can seamlessly execute on such an important and vital mission.   I am concerned that there has been no communication or coordination in any requests that have been made to the Department of Defense (DoD).  As I trust you understand, DoD has tremendous capabilities and assets that can be made available during disasters.  Have you at any point formally requested a senior general officer to be appointed and to manage the recovery effort on the ground?  Additionally, have you at any point requested an offshore medical vessel or floating hospital ‚Äì akin to the USNS Comfort ‚Äì be made available to USVI residents, a particularly helpful asset given the current status of our hospitals?     Finally, I have read news reports and also been informed by many of my Congressional colleagues on the House Appropriations Committee ‚Äì the committee which allocates federal dollars ‚Äì that you have indicated $750 million will be sufficient for our rebuilding process in the Virgin Islands.  After extensive conversations with the Army Corp, developers, recovery experts, and Members of Congress intimately involved in prior recovery legislation (notably after Hurricanes Katrina and Wilma and Superstorm Sandy), this amount seems to be a mere fraction of what will actually be needed in the long-term.  Can you please verify this amount and your rationale?  I believe we cannot undercut or in any way minimize our true need, but instead be positioned to fight for every last federal dollar to ensure our territory and its people can be made whole after the historic devastation we have just endured.     Since even before Hurricane Irma made landfall on St. John, I have made it a point to rally behind your leadership ‚Äì which during a disaster is rightfully entrusted to chief executives at the state, territorial and local levels ‚Äì to immediately respond and protect our people.  As the immediate relief and emergency response in the USVI shifts to a rebuild and long-term recovery phase, I will be consulted by many stakeholders in Washington and on Capitol Hill tasked with allocating and accounting for federal resources.  Any real or perceived lack of transparency or communication from your office on the specific needs and current gaps that might exist will only diminish individuals‚Äô confidence in us and hamper our collective ability to provide the greatest immediate and long-term support to our people.     I am returning to the territory today with Vice President Pence and wish to meet with you to discuss collaboration on federal requests as the USVI continues to recover and rebuild.  Our proud Virgin Islanders are looking to us in their greatest time of need to fight for them and show strength to the rest of the United States and the world.
